item.title: VERBS
item.description: Here is a selection of resources and channels you can use to do just that. Limited to the basic verbs, leaving out the special and more complex ones (verbs of motion, verbs on -ся, verbs with prepositions) for the most part.

item.title: Fifth Case: Instrumental
item.description: Usage Professions We say: he works as a lawyer, or: he is a lawyer. Russian can do that without “as” or “is.” Кем он работает = what does he work as, what is his profession. Кто (who) in the instrumental case.

item.title: The letter ы
item.description: Sounds Like An indescribable sound, indeed. But people have tried. Wikipedia loosely describes it as “like the u in bunker” (which is far off). Wikibooks says it’s somewhere between “u” and “j”, while Russisch in Rusland compares it to something between “u” and “i”.

item.title: Third Case: Dative
item.description: Use дательный падеж when someone or something receives something. Here’s how and when to use it. Usage You use дательный падеж in the following situations. Indirect Object When something is given or directed at someone. Often, the recipient is a person, and the dative case takes over the role of “to” or “for.

item.title: Dead or Reviving: Russian Villages
item.description: Presented in order of release. Lost A somber depiction of the потерянное богатство страны, the lost wealth of the nation. ‘How Russia is dying.’ Subtitles available in settings. Как погибает Россия. Разруха, воровство и смерть в русской деревне (Varlamov, 16-04-2020, 48 m)

item.description: Learn more in What is отчество in Russian?!
